title: Is it right to say 'My life is much easier without pets. I know I probably end up getting a lot of backlash for this.'? Can I use “for” in this sentence instead of “against”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is it right to say "My life is much easier without pets. I know I probably end up getting a lot of backlash for this."? Can I use “for” in this sentence instead of “against”? The question is invalid as you do not use “against” in the sentence so you cannot replace it with “for”. (I think you meant them the other way round.) It is also two sentences, not one. The second sentence is ungrammatical. It should read “I will probably”. That being said, it does not say what the “this” is. Is it making the choice, or, stating your choice? Getting back to the original question, it is probably best left as “for” as “against” might be less clear. (Funny how for and against are often opposites but not in this case.) Finally I would like to say that ‘easier’ does not mean ‘better’. You probably have family and friends. They sometimes bring you unwanted complications. It would probably be easier without them in your life too, but given the choice, you would choose to have them in your life.

Is it right to say "My life is much easier without pets. I know I probably end up getting a lot of backlash for this."? Can I use “for” in this sentence instead of “against”? For is correct, as we understand it to mean ‘for the decision’. I have made a correction to the first sentence. ‘My life is much easier without pets. I know I will probably end up getting a lot of backlash for this.’
